text:
>> I would love to
introduce Michael Lepech. He is an Associate Professor of

Civil and Environmental
Engineering and a senior fellow at
the Woods Institute for the Environment at
Stanford University.

As an instructor, he has taught numerous executive education and professional
education courses
on topics of finance, leadership, sustainability, and entrepreneurship in the US,

Brazil, France, Korea,
South Africa, and China. He's cofounded four
companies in the US and

China based on his research and advanced
construction materials. Michael joined Stanford
University faculty

from the University
of Michigan School of Natural Resources
and Environment. Michael Fors is

an Executive Leader in
Boeing's leadership, learning and
organizational capability,

LLOC team, driving transformation
toward a 2025 vision.

Before Boeing, he was an Executive Leader of
Learning at Microsoft, transforming Microsoft sales,
consulting services and

other divisions to achieve Microsoft's digital
transformation vision. Michael is an
adjunct professor at

Stanford University and the
University of Washington, where he teaches numerous courses on innovation and
entrepreneurism.

With that, I'm going
to go ahead and turn it over to our
wonderful speakers today

so you can all enjoy the wealth of knowledge they have
to share with you.
Thank you, Michael and Michael. >> Thanks, Hana, and Dr. Fors,

thank you so much for taking the time to spend
with me today to chat

about this really cool
topic of entrepreneurship.

I'd like to frame
today's discussion around for those that are

familiar with late
night US television, sort of a David
Letterman style top 10,

in which we talk about some of the top 10 things that
can happen anywhere.

In this case, if it's possible, I'd like to talk about
the top 10 things

that can go wrong
with the startup, talking about some failure modes.

I think by looking at those
things that can go wrong, I think there's a tremendous
amount to learn there in how

to prevent things from going wrong and how to
make them go right.

I know there's a few
of these that I think you're thinking are probably more important than others
and maybe we can

spend a little bit more time on them. Does that sound okay? >> Sounds perfect to
me, and thanks for

inviting me. I'm glad
to be here with you. >> Number 10, once again,

not in any order of importance but one that I actually think
is incredibly important.

Number 10 is going to be
competitive landscape. How was this a challenge

and how should startups
think about this? >> I'll just say thanks
again for having me.

It's April Fool's Day, so I was a little leery
when you said, "Hey, let's do this
on April 1st." I was like, "What's going on?

[LAUGHTER] Mr. Lepech might have some shenanigans
up his sleeve." Landscape, I think,
is really important.

By the way, everything
we're going to talk about is a system of interdependencies
for a startup.

There are lots of numerous failure points as we go
through these top 10. They're all interlinked
as I think about them.

I'll just say as
we start too that 70-80 percent of startups fail. We're going to talk
about the top 10 list

of reasons why they fail and
what you can do about them  . In terms of landscape, I'll just say in my mind,

the world is spinning
a bit faster. It's so funny because I was doing a class for Columbia
U actually  recently and I

was looking at my whole part
of my hypothesis about the future of work
and how it's changing was that it feels like the
world spinning faster,

partly because of the Fourth
Industrial Revolution and all this
accelerating technology. Then I went to look at
the World Economic Forum,

and there are some
scientific proof that the world will
spin a little bit, one second faster this year than other years. Crazy, I know.

But in terms of landscape, I think that means things
are changing more quickly, particularly because
we had the pandemic,

you have COVID unemployed, then you have the Fourth Industrial
Revolution technologies still progressing all
the stuff in the Cloud.

If you're a startup,
you've got to be watching your landscape more closely than
ever because it's shifting faster than ever.

The best thing that I think
we've seen over the years, as we've taught to startups,

is the idea of a
PESTLE, P-E-S-T-L-E, you may have heard of that,
but it's really looking

at the political, economic, social, technological, legal, and environmental factors
that can impact your startup.

I'll just say real quickly because it's
changing more rapidly, you shouldn't just do that once,

which is a lot of
what startups do, they do it once for a V1 product. You need to do it every 3-6

months or even more often because the competition is changing and the landscape shifting much
more quickly these days.

>> Now I think that
PESTLE framework is really useful in this case. The other thing I would say about

competitive landscape is making sure that you really understand who your
actual competitors are,

and not only looking at companies that appear to
be doing the same thing, but companies that are also

offering a similar value
proposition to the customer. Zoom is not only competing with

Skype and with Teams and
with others, but also, with many other different types of co-working platforms and

even regular offices when people are allowed to
return to offices.

So seeing that
competitive landscape as broadly as possible from
the customer viewpoint.

I think the PESTLE framework is really helpful in
allowing folks to do that.

>> Maybe one quick
follow up there too that I see is people sometimes, they'll say, "We don't
have any competition.

We're in a really new space, maybe a new technology." Well, that's probably
not true because

players that are normally not in one industry are moving
into different industries. We've seen that at
Boeing with SpaceX.

SpaceX came in and really has taken a share
of the satellite market. You have to watch out for
other players who are part of

this disruption that's happening fuled by these new
technologies in the Cloud. The people will move into other

industries and
markets, by the way, big companies are always
watching startups to either, hopefully, buy them out.

If you're a startup,
you'd like that. But also, maybe just run over the top of them once
they see that there's an opportunity that a startup

is starting to take advantage of. >> First-mover
advantage is a bit of

a fallacy in many regards. Number 9, market,
how can market be

a source of failure
for a new startup? >> We have some
colleagues at Stanford,
who really pushed for this one is a top priority because there's so much failure around it.

A lot of it's around the
size of the opportunity, so it does link to scaling,

but also, it's segmentation. Who are you going after first? We see startup folks
really conflicted

about who their target market is, and how they're
going to segment it? Who do they go after 1st, 2nd,
3rd, 4th, what order? What's speed? That creates just a whole lot of

chaos in a startup
because they're really unclear about the audience

that they're going
to serve first and how to meet their
needs and then have it flow into future audiences.

How much do you
customize and tailor for a first segment versus having the messaging and the
product and its features

be able to flow into
other markets afterward. I think segmentation is key,

and then how to sell
which channels, and also, pricing is an issue
being able to really set

a price that valid and
you can rely upon.

>> Talking about some red
flags, just like you said, a red flag is we don't
have any competitors.

That's never true.
Everyone has competitors. Similarly, when we asked folks, who's your market?
Everyone's my market.
That's also a big red flag. No, not everyone is your market. If you think that's the case,

then you don't have
enough focus to truly be able to serve anyone really well even the most
successful products.

If we think about
something like Windows, where a license on
Windows still get sold every second of the day or

every couple of
seconds of the day. One of the most
successful products ever,
even that doesn't serve everyone, so I think it's a great point.

Number 8, financials. This isn't just
about raising money,

raising money is
always a challenge, but this is more than
just raising money. >> This is really where

a lot of hard work
has to be done, a lot of details need
to be figured out. The decisions and assumptions

that get made in
a financial model and a financial plan are really strategic decisions
that drive your startup.

You've got to be able to answer the tough questions about
really, the product, its features, the competition,

the timing, and all of it
plays into a financial model. Those assumptions
and decisions really

set a lot of your strategy if you haven't
already figured it out. But you should know your income,

your expenses, your
assets, your cash flow, and then how much external
money you want because

VC money is the most expensive
money you'll ever receive. They're expecting
9x return at least,

and so you've got to be careful
because they also delete your ownership so a
lot of plays into this in cap tables and ownership,

but you've got to have your
arms around the financials. There are people who are
really strong product,

people who don't really want to deal with
financials much. You got to get help where
you can because financials,

it's something that you need
to know as a startup leader, and you've got to do the
due diligence on it.

>>It's an interesting
point and that when you talk to an investor and you say,

"Look, I'm looking to raise five million dollars
on 20 percent share."

Their first question will
be, "Why five million? What do you need it for?" If that number just
comes out of thin air,

that's another one
of those red flags. I want to know exactly what

does your operating
stock look like? What are you going to spend
this money on this quarter, next quarter, and
the quarter after?

Without having those specifics
for folks to drill down. So much about venture
capital and investing,

this is about trust
because you truly have to trust the people you're
going into business with,

which your investor is going
into business with you. If you don't have those
numbers to back it up and to understand
those financials,
that trust will never be built. >> Yeah. I totally agree.

>> Next up, and this is one
of our heavy hitters out of the top 10, number 6, product.

How does product get messed up? >> Well, the product
is where a lot of people focus and for good reason,

it needs to be really
clear what the product is and some startup leaders have trouble describing
their product.

Maybe it's because they haven't also prioritized
features and know exactly what the customer
wants and will pay

for in a V1 or a next version. Being really clear and
prioritizing what the product is,

what its features are, and doing research around
the product to make sure it's differentiated
with competitors.

If you're looking to research and you're looking to standard
sources like Gardner,

that's too late, those are
lagging research data. If you're really cutting
edge and differentiated,

there's probably not
much written about your product and its competitors, so the thing you need to
do is talk to customers.

You need to go out and develop some personas
and really think through what are the features
that this product needs.

Again, it plays into
market segmentation. How does it play into
that first segment and future segments of
what you're building?
It's about scope of prioritized features and startups just aren't really clear on that.

Every feature you decide to do is a trade off for a
feature you're not doing.

Being clear about that, I
think, is really critical. >> It's true that you
only have so much time.
Can you talk a little bit about, particularly for folks coming maybe from larger companies,

how product development and coming up with that product
is a little bit different at

a big company versus at a
startup and what some of those differences might be for
folks coming from industry, having worked for a big company, wanting to think about a startup.

Yes, a lot of it starts
with that product idea. How is that product
development process a little bit different?

>>  A page from Microsoft. I led a strategy team there and we looked at entrepreneurism
and how that plays out.

Some things are similar
in the sense that prioritizing features
is critical. At a big company, they may have

enough resources where they can pivot and throw more money and resources at
something and recover if they're seeing that
something's not working.

In a startup, you may
have a more thin edge of resources to be able to pivot as

often and throw as
many resources at it. You don't want to burn
through a whole lot of VC money in a haphazard way.

But some things that are similar, getting priority
around the features. I mean, when I was at Microsoft,

a lot of the product folks are technologists and they
feel they can do anything.

It's not okay just
because you can build it, that you need to go build it. It's like you get
bloated feature sets

that you can't
accomplish in a timeline to meet a market window because all this is meant to achieve

a market window where your products are going
to be hot in the market. I've seen it happen where
you get too many features,

product managers fighting over which features should go in, saying that they have
customer data and it

gets too bloated
and you can't meet the timeline so
suddenly you need to start cutting out features. In a startup, that can ruin you.

So you've got to be
really careful upfront and go conservatively
with a first version,

knowing you can add things and
place things in over time. >> Now, it's a bit
of a balancing act

between making sure
you don't have that bloated product
with a ton of features and yet delivering,

thinking back to
Jeff Moore's concept of a whole product solution.

You want to make
sure that you don't bloat it with
features that aren't necessarily offering
value proposition

to your focus neutral
customer segment. But also, this notion of

whole product solution where you're providing the
entire solution, not just one little bitty
widget in a much bigger thing,

which big companies
understand well. Can you talk also
maybe a little bit about this juxtaposition between

whole product solution and
that bloated feature set? >> Yeah, for sure.

It's what's the
minimum viable product that meets the customer need. Yet, what we also see,

and this happened at a lot
of the Stanford programs, is startup folks think
about the technology or the product itself and its

features and struggle with that, but don't think about
the whole product model. What other kinds of services
can be provided along with

it that generate value
that you can charge for? What about training?
What about ongoing work?

There's a story out of
France that I love. There was new technology
to have sensors to

monitor nuclear power
plants and dams. The gentleman created it out of

his garage basically and had this really cool technology
that he had developed to

sense if something was wrong
with a plant or a factory. He went to the leader
who managed these dams.

Dams, if they break, you have all these
villages downstream and cities and people will die.

He said, "Hey, I've got
this cool technology, " and the leader said, "Well, let's see it."

So they did a demo and he's like, "Well, what are you
charging for it?" He just said, "Well,
for the software maybe

12,000 Euros," and the leader of the dam started
laughing and he's like,

"Are you kidding me,
do you what happens if the dam breaks and
why haven't you thought through the services

and the maintenance and the
training of my people?" He goes, "Do you
know what my budget is to try to keep these dams

safe and similarly for
nuclear power plants?" Our friendly startup
gentleman who went

through our program
by the way and so we helped him said, "Well, I think I could go back
and think through some of these whole product
features but if I did that,

what would you be
willing to pay?" The leader of the dam said, "How about 300 thousand
Euros for the dam?"

Our startup CEO said, "Okay. Great." He tried to keep his composure and
then the leader said,

"By the way, I've 12 dams and I'll pay 300
thousand for each dam." [LAUGHTER] It's that kind

of story about whole
product model. >> Totally. Next up, number 5.

Technology disruption,
how can that be a challenge when
it comes to startups?

>> Oh my gosh, I talk about this a
lot because this is really Fourth Industrial
Revolution and just quickly,

if you're not familiar with
it, I'll just say real fast. The first one was all 1800s,

think Charles Dickens
mechanization. >> It was all about
steam and water power,

so think factories in
London belching out smoke. Then fast-forward 1900s,

Henry Ford assembly
line electricity. That was the next one,
the second revolution. Third was the personal
computing revolution.

People still think we're there, IT servers in the
basement, but we've moved.

The holy grail at Microsoft was to put the operating
system in the Cloud. So having Azure, or
AWS from Amazon,

and having Cloud technology
has changed the world. We don't even realize all the computing power
now that we have.

It's not just putting
Excel and PowerPoint, and Word in the Cloud, it is AI, it is machine learning,

it is advanced robotics, it's quantum computing
that's coming. This disruption is changing

the world and will
change all of our lives. It will affect health care, manufacturing,
agriculture, everything.

This is a great opportunity for all of you as startup folks because it is a
greenfield blank canvas.

People are moving in fast because there's a lot of disruption
in markets happening. But it also means if
you're a startup person,

you've got to watch this because things are changing
out from under you. It's not okay to do an analysis of your
competition in the technology

and then just assume as
you build out V1 over the course of months in a year
that nothing has changed.

That's where startups will
fail as they're not staying up on the technology that's
changing every few months.

>> Doing a startup is
not a full time job. It's like four full time jobs.

It's hard to keep abreast
of everything that's going on while also keeping your head

down and focused on what
you need to do that day, which is where really
great investors can be

important in forming
that advisory board and that board of directors,

when you get to the point where you're taking
institutional money. Because ideally they
can also help you

to stay abreast of all
those things, indeed.

Let's see here, where are we now? I think we're on number 7. This is a biggie, excuse me
number 6, customer need.
How does customer need play into a potential failure mode?

>> So much hinges on this
probably everything. We talked about the
prioritized feature set,

but it's how well
people can articulate basically a problem
statement in one sentence or

the customer need or
pain in one sentence, and it is really clear? If you're starting to look
at who your market is,

how you segment it, it connects to everything
else, financials, prioritized features.

But being really
clear that you're solving this customer
need or pain, and you're looking
to do it uniquely

or differentiated
from everyone else. It's not okay to just come
along as a startup and
reinvent what some big companies are already doing to meet needs. You just won't succeed

because then you
have problems with loyalty in trying to
acquire customers, which we'll also talk about.

But it's really honing
in on that customer need that you can uniquely meet
that is differentiated.
We always said at Microsoft, the customer is king or queen. It's all about the customer.
Worst-case, you stay disconnected from the customer and you're not close enough and haven't done

enough sampling to really
understand the customer, don't have any early
testimonials and first adopters.

We see startup people
who feel like they're assuming they know what's
needed and can be very wrong.

Then we say, "Who
have you talked to? Which customers? How many?" They can't tell us or
it's only been two or

three. That's not enough. Some product people, they're very much
into the technology,

maybe a little more introverted, and don't want to
get out and talk to customers, it's uncomfortable. But it's got to be done by
someone who's really out
there in forming the startup because everything flows from that customer need and pain.

It formulates the strategy
or vision of the startup, which then everything flows from that strategy and vision.

>> In the venture capital
investing programs, I'll use a line from a famous
a Silicon Valley investor,

that when you meet
with an entrepreneur, what you want to hear from
them and so for those

that are thinking about
doing the elevator pitch, do a quick thing, we tell them, make a
traction sandwich.

Talk about traction, do
your customers really need your product and what
kind of traction are you

having with real
customers who are paying. These are not freemium things. These are not users that
are just doing it for free

or friends and family
that are trying it out, who are real customers that
are liking your product?

First thing, talk about traction. Second thing, talk about
whatever it is you're doing. Then third thing, talk
again about traction.

You want to make that
traction sandwich; traction, pitch, traction. Because for an investor,
traction is everything.

If you can show that
customers truly need your product and are
willing to pay for it,
everything else will flow. We tell folks in pitching,
>> That's great, love it. >> Next up one as a university faculty member

that's near and dear to my heart, research and development and how investors don't fund
research projects.

How is that [inaudible] >> Yeah, there is some
great case studies where people were funded with

multi-millions of
dollars from VCs and the product still needed a lot more research
and development.

You burn through all
your money trying to finish research and development, you even get to productization.

That happens in
big companies too, where you have a research and development
team that's building

out something or thinking
they're going to help infuse something in a
product and it's not ready, and it's hard to transfer
over and all that.

because there's sometimes
great ideas that get funded and there's a big
assumption that, yes,

a leap of faith
that we can finish this research and development
and then you find out, it can't even be done or

certainly not in the timeline
with the money we have. Being really astute about really how much R&D is
left and can we do it?

Can it really be done? Then of course, there's
the problem of, that's great that
you did the R&D,

can you create a prototype, and can it be potentially
mass produced? Whether it's digital or physical,

can you scale it as a product? Can it get productized? There's some great products
sitting out there that

they can't scale enough
to be productized. We've talked about advanced
battery technology

out of Livermore Labs. It exists, it's too
expensive to scale. Too many expensive materials
need to go into it

and there's not the
manufacturing capability to make it scale for a startup. That's one example,
but that gets at

some of the R&D and
productization piece. >> Well, and one what
are the other pieces to

that is also often a misunderstanding by the
founder or the entrepreneur on

the cost distribution between
research and development. You feel great when
the research is

done, the ideal works. Then you're like,
we're almost there.

Development is far
more expensive, and this gets to
that productization.

Development is actually more expensive than the
initial research because you have to get to

that point where it
is productizeable. So as you think about
the financials,

we were talking before about how everything's connected together, making sure that you realize
that development is going to

be 3x or more expensive than all the research you had to
do to get to this point.

Making sure that
you're budgeting for that appropriately with regard to fundraising and also with

the staff and other resources you're going to
need to get there. >> There's a great
story about E Ink,

the ink that's used
for the kindle, where they received a lot

of venture capital
money originally and failed because they hadn't done enough research and then they couldn't get it to a state of

development where they
can productize it. So the company went bankrupt,
the startup failed.
But a couple of people kept the idea going in their garage and found a way to not only

finish the research on their own, but also then to get it to that productization
development stage

where people could
actually buy it. But it took the startup failing first before it could
come back from the ashes.

>> Yeah, right on. Another one of our heavy
hitters coming down to the last few on the top 10 list.

This one I know is near and dear to your heart
with your background. Leadership team and culture,

how can that be a problem for
a startup or a small team? >> Oh my gosh, there's so
much to talk about here

and this gets called the number one reason
why startups fail. Everyone think it's financials or it's the product or
it's the go to market.

The leadership team and culture
can make something fail more quickly and faster and
worse than anything else.

[LAUGHTER] Most people don't have a good plan around this, they just assume we'll
start bringing people

on board and we'll just find good people who have
expertise that can help us and not really
thinking about [OVERLAPPING].

>> My buddy knows
how to do something, let's have him do it. Yeah, a lot of times
friends and buddies.

[OVERLAPPING] Sorry, go ahead. >> If you've got too
many people with

the same last name
on the cap table, this is not an
investable company, this is a family
business. [LAUGHTER]

>> It's a hobby, it's a family business,
keep it that way, don't try to make
it a startup that's going to scale globally.

Just keep it a hobby, a family business in
private if you want. As you start to bring
people together,

first of all there's a
leadership issue that the leader who got the
idea started and maybe got

it funded with VC money may absolutely not be
the right person to lead the company forward.

Because they can't
build an organization, a high-performing
organization that really can execute
and scale a product.

Maybe they're all about the big ideas and we have
some leaders today who

get in big companies
that were startups who get criticized for being big idea people
who can't execute.
I won't call out any names, but you can guess a few probably, from the media [LAUGHTER].

You know who I'm talking
about, Mr. Lepech. The leadership is a real issue.

You don't want to have to fire a CEO or CTO and I've
been involved in that, actually, in startups
and it's brutal.

I was involved in a
situation where the CTO was a little bit of a bully and
the Chief Software Developer,
larger stature man, really tall, we were meeting as
a leadership team and talking about the issues the startup was having and when everyone walked out of the room and I was
sitting with this gentleman, he actually started having tears because he felt like he'd been

bullied by the CTO so much. Actually, it got involved in the firing of this
CTO, which was brutal.

But worse is firing a CEO because that's a chance really where the
venture capitalists,

if there's money involved
or feel like they need a swoop in and
actually take over. Talking about ownership dilution

or a chance for a startup to fail is when people see that
a CEO has to be taken out.

By the way, it's
worse though if a CEO stays and they're really
bad as a leader because people start not
wanting to come and

work with that in that startup. They'll start not showing up and you'll see all kinds
of cultural issues.

But a lot of things go into this leadership team and culture, it's the culture and values. We've seen startups
that have grown,

that have struggled
with their culture. You've seen Uber
having that problem,

for example, they had major culture issues
around culture and values. So not doing this intentionally
and having a strategy.

There's a whole leadership
system that I teach that gets a leadership team and culture

to really create a
high-performing organization. If you don't have that, which most people don't and
they don't think about it,

it's a real chance for failure. >> When we're teaching
our venture capital

investing and we're giving people pointers on what do you look for in
those early stages? We say the first thing
you look for is team,

the second thing you
look for is team, the third thing you
look for is team, and then you can start
looking at some other things

because a great team will
always figure it out. A second class team will
screw up even the best ideas.

>> Yeah. >> We think that you invest
in people, not in companies.
>> I think that's a great point. The VCs are looking to see what kind of background you have,

how strong you are as a leader, do you have a good
team around you? Is the team really
working well together?

They'll invest in that
first thinking that the financials and
the product will pivot maybe numerous times and

they assume that
they're okay with that, it doesn't have to stay
the same product and feature set and financials
that they pitched

to get the money and so they're investing
in the people in the team first to make

those pivots and bring
something to life. >> It goes back to that comment I made about trust, right?

You have to trust people. You cannot trust a product, you cannot trust a specific
go-to-market strategy,

you have to trust people. [OVERLAPPING] >> Some of these are
intangibles, right?

Everyone wants to focus on ones and zeros and technology and financials and yet
it comes down to

the intangibles a lot of times whether a startup
makes it or not. >> Yeah, it comes into some of the due diligence stuff that
we talk about sometimes.
Due diligence on what? [LAUGHTER] This is an idea, three people, and a passion.

What am I going to
do due diligence on other than maybe
those individuals? Alright coming up on the last
couple, customer acquisition.

I think this has a
lot to do with how hard it is to acquire customers. >> This is an area that I see

startup folks not
focus on enough. They assume if the
technology is good enough, if it's differentiated and it
has the right feature set,

that you build it
and they will come. But there's a cost to acquiring customers

to acquire customers.
